Robert Scheffel wrote:
 >

> ONe thing that could be a gotcha is that, when you define your ClassPath, 
> there can be no spaces between the semi colon separated paths in the 
> ClassPath.
> 
> I had a space after the .; (current directory) path, and apparently all 
> paths thereafter were not being honored.  As a saftey check, make sure you 
> have no stray spaces in your CP definition.
>


You can use the freely available JWhich 
(http://www.clarkware.com/software/jwhich.zip) to validate the 
classpath.  It will report any non-existent or invalid classpath 
elements.  JWhich can also be used to determine the exact class on the 
file system that will be loaded by the class loader, if any.


Example usage:

   > java JWhich -validate

   > java JWhich junit.framework.TestCase


Mike
